body: Thanks for the great bug report. The message goes away if you alphabetize "re" before "requests". In this case with a multiple import statement I agree emitting one message is best (five messages that are clearer would be acceptable too, but probably harder to implement and less intuitive.)

rename.from: Senseless C0411 - import x should be placed before import x (wrong-import-order)
rename.to: wrong-import-order emits multiple identical messages for multiple imports on single line

body:
Can I work on this?  I've figured out a way to possibly implement a clearer message to something like:
`standard import "re" should be placed before "requests" (wrong-import-order)`
if the import is `import request, re`

I need to refine the logic to handle the example case in the issue, where there are more than 2 imports.  It's possible that this can then be leveraged to avoid repeating messages, but that will need further investigation.
Of course! Thanks for lending a hand ðŸ¤

I'm not sure it's easy to do, we use isort to raise this message or not so we'd need to re-implement the logic in pylint with all the false positives that can happen if we disagree with isort. (And we could use ruff in the future instead of isort, complicating things further)
Oh I definitely agree we shouldn't reimplement isort. I just figured some light deduplication of the resulting messages was the ticket.

After taking a look at the code, I made some changes in the strings provided to the wrong-import-message string to clarify what the message trigger.  Now for the imports in the initial issue, pylint will output:

`test.py:7:0: C0410: Multiple imports on one line (requests, re, signal, time, timeit, logging) (multiple-imports)
test.py:7:0: C0411: standard import "re" should be placed before "requests" (wrong-import-order)
test.py:7:0: C0411: standard import "signal" should be placed before "requests" (wrong-import-order) 
test.py:7:0: C0411: standard import "time" should be placed before "requests" (wrong-import-order)   
test.py:7:0: C0411: standard import "timeit" should be placed before "requests" (wrong-import-order) 
test.py:7:0: C0411: standard import "logging" should be placed before "requests" (wrong-import-order)
`

Instead of 5 identical messages, each one specifies the offending import and where it should be placed.  If an import is out of order relative to several, the message ends with `...should be placed before "import1, import2"` with the hope of streamlining changes needed to clear the message.

Is this along the lines of what would be expected to address this issue or should these also be consolidated in a single message (i.e., add logic to suggest the correct order of imports *when on a single line*) to add brevity?
Yes I think it's better ! There's a problem in the logic though because ``time`` should be placed after ``requests`` not before ?

> Yes I think it's better ! There's a problem in the logic though because `time` should be placed after `requests` not before ?

I'm not sure.  From what I can tell, the code is checking the category returned from `isort`'s add_module and using that to check import order, so it is seeing `time` as a standard import and `requests` as a third-party import, so `time` should be before `requests` based on that.

I think before I made the change, I couldn't reproduce the finding [here](https://github.com/pylint-dev/pylint/issues/8808#issuecomment-1615895763) (I need to double check and will do that).  So is it possible that there is something wrong or missing in the logic if this is the correct or expected behavior.

I will check more into the code and previous behavior compared to new behavior.  Is there a certain rule or convention that should be part of the logic to enforce this ordering, if it is not already present?

> I'm not sure. From what I can tell, the code is checking the category returned from isort's add_module and using that to check import order, so it is seeing time as a standard import and requests as a third-party import, so time should be before requests based on that.

Ha, you're right, request is a third party library not time.  Maybe adding the reason in parenthesis would be nice but keeping it simple and stupid is nice too. (Disclaimer: I'm not using this message myself because isort/ruff can automate the fix).

> > I'm not sure. From what I can tell, the code is checking the category returned from isort's add_module and using that to check import order, so it is seeing time as a standard import and requests as a third-party import, so time should be before requests based on that.
> 
> Ha, you're right, request is a third party library not time. Maybe adding the reason in parenthesis would be nice but keeping it simple and stupid is nice too. (Disclaimer: I'm not using this message myself because isort/ruff can automate the fix).

No worries.  Just wanted to make sure I wasn't missing something :-)  I will improve the message to provide a bit more information.

I see that PEP8 provides the "grouping" guidance for imports, but does not specify they need to be alphabetical.  I know isort does it this way, so I was wondering if that is something that pylint should check (in a new issue, if one doesn't exist yet)?

Made changes to the message to separate out each category of imports:
`standard import "re" should be placed before third party import(s) "requests" (wrong-import-order)`

In the case imports of multiple categories are out of order, the last part reads something like `...third party import(s) "requests" and first party import(s) "pylint"`.  This is more helpful to me than my original proposal, but others may find it too much information.

The only other change I can think that could be helpful is to reference PEP8 (as a parenthetical) in the message, but that may be redundant since the documentation for wrong-import-order already states this.

Any thoughts on what would be most helpful for a general user (maybe something I haven't considered yet)?

I think ``standard import "re" should be placed before third party import(s) "requests" (wrong-import-order)`` is optimal, no need to tell about pep8 in the message displayed, but there's documentation surrounding the message that you can upgrade if required (https://pylint.readthedocs.io/en/stable/user_guide/messages/convention/wrong-import-order.html)

issue.title: Correct/clarify message for wrong-import-order

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
<!--
Thank you for submitting a PR to pylint!

To ease the process of reviewing your PR, do make sure to complete the following boxes.

- [ ] Document your change, if it is a non-trivial one.
  - A maintainer might label the issue ``skip-news`` if the change does not need to be in the changelog.
  - Otherwise, create a news fragment with ``towncrier create <IssueNumber>.<type>`` which will be
    included in the changelog. ``<type>`` can be one of the types defined in `./towncrier.toml`.
    If necessary you can write details or offer examples on how the new change is supposed to work.
  - Generating the doc is done with ``tox -e docs``
- [ ] Relate your change to an issue in the tracker if such an issue exists (Refs #1234, Closes #1234)
- [ ] Write comprehensive commit messages and/or a good description of what the PR does.
- [ ] Keep the change small, separate the consensual changes from the opinionated one.
  Don't hesitate to open multiple PRs if the change requires it. If your review is so
  big it requires to actually plan and allocate time to review, it's more likely
  that it's going to go stale.
- [ ] If you used multiple emails or multiple names when contributing, add your mails
      and preferred name in ``script/.contributors_aliases.json``
-->

## Type of Changes

<!-- Leave the corresponding lines for the applicable type of change: -->

|     | Type                   |
| --- | ---------------------- |
| âœ“   | :bug: Bug fix          |

## Description
Adds clarification in the message for the wrong-import-order check.

The original message was confusing, especially when multiple imports were on a single line, because the entire import statement is listed twice in the message (`"import X, Y, Z" should be placed before "import X, Y, Z"`).

Changes were made to extract the "current" import name and the "out of order" import names, and separate them by "isort order", so the user is able to clearly see what changes need to be made to address the problem.  For example, `standard import "X" should be placed before third order import "Y" and first order import "Z"`.

No functional tests were added, but the output for the wrong-import-order test was updated to reflect the new messages produced by the change.  The code has passed the full `tox` test suite as well as all `primer` tests and a documentation fragment added to explain the changes.

<!-- If this PR fixes an issue, use the following to automatically close when we merge: -->

Closes #8808

issue.title: Release branch 3.1.0

labels.name: Maintenance

labels.name: Skip news :mute:

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
What's new in Pylint 3.1.0?
---------------------------
Release date: 2024-02-25


New Features
------------

- Skip ``consider-using-join`` check for non-empty separators if an ``suggest-join-with-non-empty-separator`` option is set to ``no``.

  Closes #8701 

- Discover ``.pyi`` files when linting.

  These can be ignored with the ``ignore-patterns`` setting.

  Closes #9097 

- Check ``TypeAlias`` and ``TypeVar`` (PEP 695) nodes for ``invalid-name``.

  Refs #9196 

- Support for resolving external toml files named pylintrc.toml and .pylintrc.toml.

  Closes #9228 

- Check for `.clear`, `.discard`, `.pop` and `remove` methods being called on a set while it is being iterated over.

  Closes #9334 



New Checks
----------

- New message `use-yield-from` added to the refactoring checker. This message is emitted when yielding from a loop can be replaced by `yield from`.

  Closes #9229. 

- Added a ``deprecated-attribute`` message to check deprecated attributes in the stdlib.

  Closes #8855 


False Positives Fixed
---------------------

- Fixed false positive for ``inherit-non-class`` for generic Protocols.

  Closes #9106

- Exempt ``TypedDict`` from ``typing_extensions`` from ``too-many-ancestor`` checks.

  Refs #9167 



False Negatives Fixed
---------------------

- Extend broad-exception-raised and broad-exception-caught to except*.

  Closes #8827 

- Fix a false-negative for unnecessary if blocks using a different than expected ordering of arguments.

  Closes #8947. 



Other Bug Fixes
---------------

- Improve the message provided for wrong-import-order check.  Instead of the import statement ("import x"), the message now specifies the import that is out of order and which imports should come after it.  As reported in the issue, this is particularly helpful if there are multiple imports on a single line that do not follow the PEP8 convention.

  The message will report imports as follows:
  For "import X", it will report "(standard/third party/first party/local) import X"
  For "import X.Y" and "from X import Y", it will report "(standard/third party/first party/local) import X.Y"
  The import category is specified to provide explanation as to why pylint has issued the message and guidence to the developer on how to fix the problem.

  Closes #8808 



Other Changes
-------------

- Print how many files were checked in verbose mode.

  Closes #8935 

- Fix a crash when an enum class which is also decorated with a ``dataclasses.dataclass`` decorator is defined.

  Closes #9100 



Internal Changes
----------------

- Update astroid version to 3.1.0.

  Refs #9457
